The text is carefully aligned on the left margin, less evenly along the right, and fills the stone over 5 lines, with a large hedera at the end of the text, lower right.

1Μ(άρκος) Ἀντώνιος
2Σκόρπος Κορίν-
3θιος ἐνθάδε κίτ-
4αι ἐτῶν κε´ χαίρετε
5οἱ προσιόντες
6❦

The inscription is cut into the stucco in the recess and the letters are painted red. Much of the bottom of the stucco has been damaged. “It is highly likely that there was a third line in the [recessed stucco] panel, and quite possible that there were further lines on a block below.” (Crawford 2011)
The text is written in the adapted Ionic Greek alphabet which was usually employed to write Oscan in Lucania and Bruttium from around the fourth to the first centuries BC.
After the Mamertine occupation in 288 BCE, perhaps soon after, and unlikely to be later than the third century.
Parlangèli, 1956, Le iscrizioni osche (mamertine) di Messina
Rix, 2002, Sabellische Texte : die Texte des Oskischen, Umbrischen und Südpikenischen
Crawford, 2011, Imagines Italicae. A Corpus of Italic Inscriptions
Crawford, 2006, The Oscan Inscriptions of Messana

l.4 ic
Latin text laid out neatly over four lines, neatly filling the available space (regular left margin, irregular right margin). Line 1 has large hedera at each end.

Neatly v-cut letters, with faint traces of guidelines. The letters have deep serifs at the end of strokes: E is often very narrow, with the horizontal bars angled upwards; M and A in the final line have extended upper strokes, tending towards cursive; interpuncts are variable in form.

Four lines of Latin letters approximately centred on the stone

Thinly but deeply incised regular letters with minimal serifs and of slightly uneven size. R has a small open eye, with a long straight tail; E is fully perpendicular with equal length strokes; M is made up four equal oblique strokes reaching to top and bottom of the line.

1 · D(is) · M(anibus) ·
2L(ucius) · Ostrius Cres-
3cens
4vix(it) ann(is) · LXXVI
Five lines of Greek text, observing a regular left margin, with hedera in the four corners

Somewhat irregular letters, tending to cursive (e.g. mu), and often leaning to the left; omega, sigma and epislon all lunate in form; theta a circle with an unconnected central bar; triangular letters tend to have a slightly extended top stroke.

l.2 reg., orig. ἔζησ σεν
Text is more or less centered and concentrated on the upper portion of the plaque, with extensive use of interpuncts. Perhaps a single letter missing from the end of line 2.
Diamond shaped theta, broken and straight-bar alpha, beta with detached loops, sigma a slightly irregular four-bar version, epsilon with upward angled cross-strokes.

Large letters that essentially fill the available surface of the stone in four lines.
Large deep letters, with slight tendency to extensions/serifs at stroke ends. Borken bar alpha (but also straight on line 2), lunate sigma, regular epsilon, use of ligature.

Text set out on centre of stone, below the tympanum (guideline marks the base of the tympanum).
Regular deeply v-cut letters with some curvature on longer strokes. Lunate sigma and epsilon; kappa has short arms. Elegant hedera at end of line 1. Phi in line 1 and Iota in line 3 are extended.
